Up to generation 832.

Discovered something relevant to anyone who is working in a domain with a 
non-deterministic fitness evaluation.  Originally, I was calculating 
stagnation by keeping track of the highest fitness value ever acheived for 
that topology.  However, since there is a certain amount of randomness to 
the fitness evaluation, there is a problem with that approach.  At one 
point, there may be an uncharacteristically high single fitness value.  For 
the next hundred generations it may be making steady progress without ever 
exceeding that single peak value.  Thus, it is deemed 'stagnant' and killed 
off.  Oops!

Instead of using the peak, I'm using a weighted average.  For each 
topology/species I keep a history of up to 100 past 'best' fitness values 
(one per generation).  The average is computed by weighting the current 
fitness at 100, the last one at 99, the one before that at 98, and so on.  
This makes for a 'running average' value that tends to follow the current 
trend fairly closely without being unduely influenced by the peaks and 
valleys of the past, making for a smoother avg line than would be acheived 
by a more typical running average.

Instead of tracking the peak fitness value, it uses the peak weighted 
average.  As long as the average max fitness is going up, the topology is 
not stagnant.  Also, to avoid anomalous results right after a topology is 
created, I do not begin checking for stagnation until I have at least 20 
historical fitness values.  The idea is that hopefully by then a meaningful 
average has been established.

I also changed the trend line in the fitness history graph to follow this 
same technique.  The trend line does a much better job of following the 
actual trend of the data, compared to before.

I have made a number of cosmetic changes to the status page.  Looks much 
better now.  Check it out:
http://www.hanlonsrazor.com:81/neat/iex/status.cgi

Finally, thanks Ian for joining in, and Collin for your continued 
contribution!

-- John
